metadata.title: Impact of the Bird-Beak Configuration on Postoperative Outcome After Thoracic Endovascular Aortic Repair: A Meta-analysis

sections.heading: Introduction
sections.text:
The bird-beak configuration after thoracic endovascular aortic repair (TEVAR) refers to the radiologically identified wedge-shaped gap between the undersurface of the endograft and the lesser curvature of the arch.1 This configuration (Figure 1) is most commonly defined by 2 specific features: the angle between the undersurface of the endograft and the aortic wall (α angle) and the length of the longitudinal segment of the endograft that protrudes in the aortic lumen (PLS).2
The α angle indicates an incomplete apposition of the proximal edge of the endograft to the lesser curvature of the arch.3 As a result, an insufficient proximal seal or endograft
1Clinical Research Unit, Cardiovascular Department, IRCCS Policlinico San Donato, Milan, Italy 2Vascular Surgery Unit, Cardiovascular Department, IRCCS Policlinico San Donato, Milan, Italy 3Residency Program in Vascular Surgery, University of Milan, Italy 4Biostatistics Service, IRCCS Policlinico San Donato, Milan Italy 5Vascular Surgery Unit, Policlinico San Marco, Zingonia, Italy 6Laboratory of Medical Statistics, University of Milan, Italy 7Department of “Scienze Biomediche per la Salute,” University of Milan, Italy

sections.heading: Corresponding Author:
sections.text: Massimiliano M. Marrocco-Trischitta, Clinical Research Unit, IRCCS Policlinico San Donato, Via Morandi 30, 20097 San Donato Milanese (Milan), Italy. Email: massimiliano.marroccotrischitta@grupposandonato.it

sections.heading: Keywords
sections.text:
aortic arch, arch angulation, bird-beak configuration, endograft, endoleak, migration, stent-graft, thoracic endovascular aortic repair
migration or both may occur, leading to a type Ia endoleak with the inherent continued risk of aortic rupture.4 The protrusion of the endograft in the aortic lumen may cause relevant hemodynamic disturbances.5 The high pulsatile forces acting on the aortic arch wall6 are transmitted as displacement forces on the terminal fixation sites of the endograft after its release,7 and this also may cause an endoleak or even the collapse of the device5 and a consequent fatal aortic occlusion.
Indeed, the advent of new devices specifically designed to conform with the arch geometry have improved the TEVAR results.8,9 The issue of the biomechanical interaction between the endograft and the aortic arch wall, however, remains largely unaddressed,7,9 and the incidence of the postoperative bird-beak configuration (BBC) has been reduced but remains anything but eliminated.9,10 Of note, a surrogate of the BBC (ie, the distance between the proximal end of the endograft and the inner curvature of the arch), was employed as a conformability index in the European Gore C-TAG registry.10
Since its first description in the literature in 2008,11 the BBC has gained the ominous reputation of heralding inadequate endograft performance.2 The literature, however, provides inconsistent evidence regarding its prognostic relevance,3,12 and these controversial results are likely to be related to methodologic differences among the studies, including patients and type of endograft, and even the choice of the definition and grading of the BBC.
The aim of this study was to systematically review the available literature to investigate the association between the BBC and postoperative outcome after arch TEVAR and assess the differences between the definitions employed among the studies.

sections.heading: Materials and Methods
sections.text: The systematic review was performed according to the Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-analyses (PRISMA) guidelines,13 and the protocol was registered on PROSPERO (number CRD42018100154; https://www.crd.york.ac.uk/PROSPERO).

sections.heading: Search Strategy
sections.text: The PubMed, EMBASE, and Cochrane databases were searched to identify all case series reporting on the BBC after TEVAR between 2006 and April 2018. A first search was performed using the terms “bird-beak” AND “TEVAR,” then a second search was made looking for complications related to bird-beak, using the following keywords: “collapse” OR “infolding” OR “endoleak” AND “bird-beak,” “collapse” OR “infolding” OR “endoleak” AND “TEVAR.” The references lists of the included articles were searched manually to identify additional publications.

sections.heading: Eligibility Criteria
sections.text: Studies reporting the development of a BBC and any related complications after TEVAR were eligible for inclusion. Studies with <2 patients in each BBC group were excluded, as were commentaries, letters, technical notes, case reports, reviews, experimental studies, conference proceedings/ abstracts, and articles in a language other than English. Articles in which the presence of a BBC was not clearly assessed among the causes of complications and case series reporting endoleak other than type Ia were also excluded.

sections.heading: Study Selection
sections.text: Titles and abstracts of all publications (1633 articles) were screened independently by 2 authors (B.S. and G.M.); disagreements were resolved by consensus. Full texts of 517 articles relevant to the study were retrieved and reviewed; no randomized trials were found, so no quality exclusion criteria were applied. Ultimately, 21 articles1–3,9,12,14–29 were retrieved for qualitative analysis (Figure 2). Characteristics of the included studies are summarized in Table 1.

sections.heading: Data Collection
sections.text: The 2 authors independently extracted the following data from text and tables: first author, publication date, study design, patient population size, pathologies treated using TEVAR, endograft models, criteria for defining a BBC, number of BBCs, risk factors for a BBC, BBC-related complications (type Ia endoleak, proximal endograft collapse/ infolding, or endograft migration) and their time to occurrence, and follow-up duration. Any discrepancies were resolved by discussion.

sections.heading: Statistical Analysis
sections.text:
Qualitative analysis was performed to evaluate the definitions employed to define a BBC, identify any risks for its development, review treatment indications, and ascertain any association with endograft models. Quantitative analysis was performed to evaluate the difference in the risk of complications related to the presence vs absence of the BBC. Two studies with 0 events and an imbalance in the 2 groups under comparison made continuity corrections not suitable, so the beta-binomial regression model suggested by Kuss30 was adopted to produce summary estimates for the pooled risk differences with 95% confidence intervals (CI). The I2 statistic was calculated to evaluate the heterogeneity of included studies; values of 25%, 50%, and 75% represented low, medium, and high heterogeneity, respectively.31 The risk of publication bias was evaluated using the Egger test and visual inspection of the funnel plot. A proportion meta-analysis using a random effects model was employed to analyze the pooled proportions of complications among patients with and without BBC (Comprehensive Meta-Analysis statistical software version 3.3; Biostat Inc, Englewood, NJ, USA); the overall proportions are presented with the 95% CI. Other statistical analyses were performed using SAS software (version 9.4; SAS
Institute, Inc, Cary, NC, USA) or the R program (http:// CRAN.R-project.org). For all tests, a 2-sided p<0.05 was considered statistically significant.

sections.heading: Results
sections.text:
The definition of the BBC was based on 2 specific features: the α angle between the undersurface of the endograft and the aortic wall and the length of the PLS (Figure 1) of the unapposed endograft. Overall, 11 articles1–3,9,15–20,22 described both features. No study reported a threshold value for the α angle, which varied between 6.12° and 51°. Five studies1,16–18,28 reported a threshold value for PLS: 5 mm in 4 articles1,16,18,28 and 3 mm in 1 article.17 The PLS length varied between 3 and 29 mm. One study2 reported a longer PLS (14.3±2.1 vs 8.4±4.1 mm, p<0.01) in complicated vs noncomplicated cases but failed to show a statically significant difference between the groups in terms of α angle (25.6°±8.9° vs 22.6°±9.3°, p=0.64).
Among anatomical features, 7 articles16–19,24,25,28 reported severe arch angulation as a risk factor for the BBC, but no consistent definition for angulation was used. Proximal landing zones 2 and 3 were also found to be associated with an increased risk of the BBC.1,2,9,19,22 One study18 reported the BBC as a common occurrence when the endograft was deployed in an ascending aortic Dacron graft during type II hybrid arch repair.
Pathologies treated in the studies included aortic aneurysm (including postdissection aneurysms) in 12 studies,1,9,12,17–21,23,24,26,28 dissections in 12 studies,1,2,9,15,16,18,22–24,26,28,29 penetrating aortic ulcer and/or intramural hematoma in 7 studies,1,2,18,19,23,25,28 and aortic trauma in 11 studies1–3,12,14,23,25–29 (Table 1). Of note, 5 studies3,12,14,25,27 specifically included only patients treated for aortic trauma. No comparison between different indications was available in terms of BBC occurrence. One study17 showed that the BBC was more common after TEVAR for dissecting aortic aneurysm than non-dissecting aneurysm. Finally, 5 studies1,9,12,17,27 compared different types of commercially available endografts, and no specific association with the BBC was found.

sections.heading: Qualitative Analysis
sections.text:
Regarding the type of complications related to the BBC, type Ia endoleak was reported in 12 studies,1–3,16–19,21–23,25,27 endograft collapse or infolding in 8 studies,2,12,18,23,25–27,29 and endograft migration in 118 (Table 1). The time between the index TEVAR and the occurrence of the complication related to the BBC ranged between 0 and 72 months.26,29
Twelve studies1–3,14,15,17–20,22,25,29 reported detailed information to analyze the impact of the BBC on postoperative outcome and were included in the quantitative analysis. Complications occurred in 14.7% (95% CI 7.4% to 27.3%)
of patients with BBC and in 6.3% (95% CI 2.5% to 15.4%) of patients without BBC (Table 2). A cumulative incidence could not be assessed. According to the meta-analysis, the summary risk difference was equal to 11.1% (95% CI −0.1% to 22.3%, p=0.052; Figure 3). The I2 was 85.6%,
indicating significant heterogeneity. The Egger test did not show any evidence of publication bias (p=0.975).
A meta-analysis for specific complications showed that when considering type Ia endoleak and endograft migration, the risk difference between patients with the BBC and

When specifically considering endograft collapse/infolding and thrombosis, the risk difference between the 2 groups was 3.7% (95% CI −3.5% to 11.1%, p=0.308; Figure 5) with low heterogeneity (I2=10.2%).

sections.heading: Discussion
sections.text:
TEVAR is a widely accepted alternative to open repair in patients with both appropriate anatomic features32 and adequate life expectancy.33 In the descending thoracic aorta, TEVAR can currently be regarded as the treatment of choice on the basis of remarkable long-term clinical success rates.34 TEVAR of the aortic arch, in contrast, remains challenging due to its peculiar geometries35 and hemodynamic environment,6,7 which may lead to an increased risk of endograft failure.32,36,37 Also, concerns persist regarding the long-term durability of endovascular treatment in the view of continuous remodeling of the arch induced by the endograft.9,38 Hence, the identification of a diagnostic sign that may account for the presence of a relevant biomechanical mismatch between the aorta and the endograft remains an important but still unaddressed issue.
The results of this analysis showed that the literature at present does not provide robust evidence to establish an overall prognostic value for the BBC. Nevertheless, it appears that this configuration is in fact associated with a high risk of postoperative adverse events. Notably, the BBC may become evident only during follow-up,9 and it
Abbreviation: BBC, bird-beak configuration.
may cause lethal complications even years after the index procedure.26,29 Unfortunately, the available studies do not report consistent and adequate follow-up analyses, so a cumulative incidence of postoperative adverse events is lacking.
The recognition of the overall clinical significance of the BBC suffers from the high heterogeneity of the retrieved studies; in addition, the relevance of both the α angle and the PLS remains to be determined. Also, no proven and shared values for the grading of these features are available. In our review, a threshold value for the α angle was not suggested in any article, and only 5 clinical studies1,16–18,28 and 1 experimental work39 reported a threshold value for the PLS. No further studies, however, were performed to validate these findings.
When addressing the risk of specific complications, we found that the BBC is in fact associated with a significant incidence of type Ia endoleak and endograft migration. This finding suggests that this configuration leads to insufficient
proximal seal of the endograft and therefore deserves specific and long-term postoperative surveillance.2 However, whether preemptive endovascular treatment or even surgical conversion is warranted in selected patients based on the presence of the BBC only remains to be established. Further studies are required to find clinically relevant criteria for the definition of the BBC to assess validated and shared indications for reintervention after TEVAR.
Our work also showed that the BBC does not appear to be associated with an increased risk of collapse/infolding or endograft thrombosis. This finding implies that the magnitude of the hemodynamic disturbances induced by the misalignment of the endograft, consistent with previous functional studies specifically performed in trauma patients,12 may not per se induce complete endograft failure. Yet, displacement forces are greater in aneurysmal aortas compared with healthy aortas (ie, nondilated aortas such as in trauma patients) in zone 3,7 and therefore clinical outcomes may vary based on the indication for TEVAR and the choice of the proximal landing zone.
Among the potential determinants of the BBC analyzed in the literature, specific anatomic risk factors are the ones most consistently reported, namely proximal landing zones 2 and 31,2,9,19,22 and aortic angulation.16–19,24,25,28 Of note, these features are often associated because zones 2 and 3 in type III arch configuration are characterized by severe angulation and tortuosity.35
Aortic arch angulation is a recognized main determinant of endograft performance,32 even though it remains illdefined and there is no consensus on its grading even among the manufacturers’ instructions for use. Also, the greater the angulation, the greater must be the length of the proximal landing zone to obtain effective deployment.40 In this respect, the BBC appears to be a sign of inadequate preoperative planning, with the inherent clinical impact.

sections.heading: Conclusion
sections.text:
The BBC represents a valuable identifier of patients who, despite a technically successful4 TEVAR, are at high risk for clinical failure4; therefore, they should be closely followed.2 Our results also warrant a thorough awareness of the detrimental clinical implications of the BBC during both preoperative planning and postoperative image interpretation.
Threshold values of the α angle and/or the length of the PLS associated with inadequate sealing and fixation of the endograft despite the apparent absence of type Ia endoleak are yet to be established. Experimental studies based on in silico endograft virtual deployment41 may represent a feasible and cutting edge first step to address this issue. Also, as previously suggested,7 the potential causative effect of the magnitude and orientation of the displacement forces exerted in the different proximal landing zones of the arch should be investigated by specific computational fluid dynamics studies.

sections.heading: Declaration of Conflicting Interests
sections.text: The author(s) declared no potential conflicts of interest with respect to the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article.

sections.heading: Funding
sections.text: The author(s) received no financial support for the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article.

In the descending thoracic aorta, TEVAR can currently be regarded as the treatment of choice on the basis of remarkable long-term clinical success rates.(34) TEVAR of the aortic arch, in contrast, remains challenging due to its peculiar geometries(35) and hemodynamic environment,(6,7) which may lead to an increased risk of endograft failure.

TEVAR of the aortic arch, in contrast, remains challenging due to its peculiar geometries(35) and hemodynamic environment,(6,7) which may lead to an increased risk of endograft failure.(32,36,37) Also, concerns persist regarding the long-term durability of endovascular treatment in the view of continuous remodeling of the arch induced by the endograft.

TEVAR of the aortic arch, in contrast, remains challenging due to its peculiar geometries(35) and hemodynamic environment,(6,7) which may lead to an increased risk of endograft failure.(32,36,37) Also, concerns persist regarding the long-term durability of endovascular treatment in the view of continuous remodeling of the arch induced by the endograft.

Also, concerns persist regarding the long-term durability of endovascular treatment in the view of continuous remodeling of the arch induced by the endograft.(9,38) Hence, the identification of a diagnostic sign that may account for the presence of a relevant biomechanical mismatch between the aorta and the endograft remains an important but still unaddressed issue.

Also, concerns persist regarding the long-term durability of endovascular treatment in the view of continuous remodeling of the arch induced by the endograft.(9,38) Hence, the identification of a diagnostic sign that may account for the presence of a relevant biomechanical mismatch between the aorta and the endograft remains an important but still unaddressed issue.

may cause lethal complications even years after the index procedure.(26,29) Unfortunately, the available studies do not report consistent and adequate follow-up analyses, so a cumulative incidence of postoperative adverse events is lacking.

may cause lethal complications even years after the index procedure.(26,29) Unfortunately, the available studies do not report consistent and adequate follow-up analyses, so a cumulative incidence of postoperative adverse events is lacking.

This finding suggests that this configuration leads to insufficient proximal seal of the endograft and therefore deserves specific and long-term postoperative surveillance.(2) However, whether preemptive endovascular treatment or even surgical conversion is warranted in selected patients based on the presence of the BBC only remains to be established.

Of note, these features are often associated because zones 2 and 3 in type III arch configuration are characterized by severe angulation and tortuosity.(35) Aortic arch angulation is a recognized main determinant of endograft performance,(32) even though it remains illdefined and there is no consensus on its grading even among the manufacturers’ instructions for use.

Also, the greater the angulation, the greater must be the length of the proximal landing zone to obtain effective deployment.(40) In this respect, the BBC appears to be a sign of inadequate preoperative planning, with the inherent clinical impact.

The BBC represents a valuable identifier of patients who, despite a technically successful(4) TEVAR, are at high risk for clinical failure(4); therefore, they should be closely followed.(2) Our results also warrant a thorough awareness of the detrimental clinical implications of the BBC during both preoperative planning and postoperative image interpretation.

metadata.abstractText: Purpose: To investigate the association between the bird-beak configuration (BBC), a wedge-shaped gap between the undersurface of a thoracic endograft and the lesser curvature of the arch after thoracic endovascular aortic repair (TEVAR), and postoperative outcome after TEVAR. Methods: The study was performed according to the PRISMA guidelines. The PubMed, EMBASE, and Cochrane databases were searched to identify all case series reporting BBC after TEVAR between 2006 and April 2018. Data analysis was performed considering the difference in the risk of complications for presence vs absence of BBC. After screening 1633 articles, 21 studies were identified that matched the selection criteria; 12 of these reported detailed information to investigate the postoperative outcome using proportion meta-analysis with a random effects model. The pooled risk difference is reported with the 95% confidence interval (CI). Heterogeneity of the included studies was assessed with the I statistic (low 25%, medium 50%, high 75%). Results: Complications occurred within a range of 0 to 72 months in 14.7% (95% CI 7.4% to 27.3%) of patients with BBC and in 6.3% (95% CI 2.5% to 15.4%) of patients without BBC. A cumulative incidence could not be assessed. The summary risk difference was 11.1% (95% CI −0.1% to 22.3%, p=0.052). There was significant heterogeneity (I=85.6%). The Egger test did not show evidence of publication bias (p=0.975). When specifically considering type Ia endoleak and endograft migration, the risk difference between BBC and non-BBC patients was 8.2% (95% CI 0.3% to 16.1%, p=0.042; I=69.0%). The specific risk difference for endograft collapse/infolding and thrombosis was 3.7% (95% CI −3.5% to 11.1%, p=0.308; I=10.2%). Conclusion: At present the literature does not provide statistical evidence to establish an overall prognostic value of the BBC. Nevertheless, the BBC appears to be associated with a high risk of type Ia endoleak and endograft migration, which warrants specific and long-term surveillance. Clinically relevant values for BBC grading should be established to perhaps define indications for preemptive treatment based on the presence of BBC only.
